choices.D: Adjust the peer IP address on the remote peer to direct traffic back to the ASA.
choices.A: Adjust the routing on the remote peer device to direct traffic back over the tunnel.
choices.B: Adjust the preshared key on the remote peer to allow traffic to flow over the tunnel.
choices.C: Adjust the transform set to allow bidirectional traffic.

questions.question_text: A user at a company HQ is having trouble accessing a network share at a branch site that is connected with a L2L IPsec VPN. While troubleshooting, a network security engineer runs a packet tracer on the Cisco ASA to simulate the user traffic and discovers that the encryption counter is increasing but the decryption counter is not. What must be configured to correct this issue?

discussion.content: To correct the issue of encryption counter increasing but the decryption counter not increasing in a L2L IPsec VPN scenario, it is likely that the routing on the remote peer device needs to be adjusted to direct traffic back over the tunnel. When traffic is sent over a L2L IPsec VPN, it is encrypted at the source and decrypted at the destination. If the encryption counter is increasing but the decryption counter is not, it suggests that the encrypted traffic is not reaching the destination properly for decryption. In this case, it is recommended to review the routing configuration on the remote peer device. Ensure that the routes are properly configured to direct the traffic destined for the HQ network (where the network share is located) over the IPsec VPN tunnel. By adjusting the routing on the remote peer device to correctly route traffic back over the tunnel, the encrypted traffic will reach the destination (HQ network) and get decrypted, resolving the issue of the decryption counter not increasing.
answer should be A since the tunnel is working 1 way...peer needs to know the way back definately with routing

questions.question_text: A user is experiencing delays on audio calls over a Cisco AnyConnect VPN. Which implementation step resolves this issue?

discussion.content: DDD sounds better since DTLS improves latency

choices.C: Install the Cisco AnyConnect 2.3 client for the user to download.

choices.B: Have the user upgrade to a supported browser.
choices.C: Increase the simultaneous logins on the group policy.
choices.A: Enable the Cisco AnyConnect premium license on the Cisco ASA.
choices.D: Enable the clientless VPN protocol on the group policy.

discussion.content: To resolve the issue of users unable to log in to a Cisco ASA using clientless SSLVPN and encountering the error message "WebVPN session terminated: Client type not supported," the administrator should enable the clientless VPN protocol on the group policy. The "Client type not supported" error message typically indicates that the clientless SSLVPN feature on the Cisco ASA is not enabled or the configured group policy does not allow clientless VPN connections. By enabling the clientless VPN protocol on the group policy, you allow users to connect using the clientless SSLVPN method. Enabling the Cisco AnyConnect premium license on the Cisco ASA is not directly related to resolving this particular issue. The premium license is needed if you want to use the Cisco AnyConnect VPN client software instead of the clientless SSLVPN method. In summary, to address the login issue and overcome the "Client type not supported" error message, the administrator should focus on enabling the clientless VPN protocol on the group policy. This will allow users to establish a clientless SSLVPN connection to the Cisco ASA successfully.

Selected Answer: D
D. I tested it and confirmed 

Group <SALES> User <webvpn> IP <172.1.5.200> WebVPN session terminated: Client type not supported.
I have my doubts. This error appears to be related to licensing issues as clientless ssl vpn needs premium. So A!?

questions.question_text: Users cannot log in to a Cisco ASA using clientless SSLVPN. Troubleshooting reveals the error message "WebVPN session terminated: Client type not supported". Which step does the administrator take to resolve this issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Wow. This isn't rocket science.

comments.content:
A smart tunnel is a connection between a TCP-based application and a private site, using a clientless (browser-based) SSL VPN session with the security appliance as the pathway, and the adaptive security appliance as a proxy server. You can identify applications to which you want to grant smart tunnel access, and specify the local path to each application. For applications running on Microsoft Windows, you can also require a match of the SHA-1 hash of the checksum as a condition for granting smart tunnel access.
https://community.cisco.com/t5/security-knowledge-base/asa-ssl-vpn-smart-tunnel/ta-p/3120099

discussion.content: After reviewing this further, I think that B.) smart tunneling is the correct answer. Clientless Plug-ins would be appropriate if the Microsoft RDP wasn't blocked. CCNP Security SVPN 300-730 pg. 301

C is the correct answer. CCNP Security SVPN 300-730 pg. 301, Configuring Client/Server Plug-ins. Client/server plug-ins allow administrators to extend the applications supported by a client-less SSL VPN to include applications such as RDP, VNC, Telnet, and SSH.

To allow users to access an internal RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol) server without running the Microsoft RDP client on client workstations, the appropriate VPN feature to implement is smart tunneling.

Smart tunneling is a feature that enables the SSL VPN client to dynamically launch applications based on policies. In this case, it would allow users to access the RDP server without relying on the Microsoft RDP client being installed or running locally on their workstations. Smart tunneling provides a way to tunnel specific applications through the SSL VPN connection.

Therefore, for the described scenario, the recommended VPN feature is smart tunneling.

comments.content: Rdp client is blocked on client machine, how user can run the rdp client even smart tunnelling is enabled?

discussion.content: "B", smart tunneling is the correct answer here.

questions.question_text: An administrator is setting up a VPN on an ASA for users who need to access an internal RDP server. Due to security restrictions, the Microsoft RDP client is blocked from running on client workstations via Group Policy. Which VPN feature should be implemented by the administrator to allow these users to have access to the RDP server?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C makes sense:

The VPN technology that must be used for this task is GETVPN (Group Encrypted Transport VPN). GETVPN is designed to encrypt both unicast and multicast traffic while preserving the original source and destination IP addresses, and it does not require any changes to the existing routing infrastructure. Additionally, GETVPN provides a scalable and efficient solution for encrypting traffic within a network, making it a good choice for this scenario.

questions.question_text: An administrator is planning a VPN configuration that will encrypt traffic between multiple servers that will be passing unicast and multicast traffic. This configuration must be able to be implemented without the need to modify routing within the network. Which VPN technology must be used for this task?
